children.name: sth must happen before sth else can happen
condition
children.definition: /kənˈdɪʃən/  điều kiện
examples: condition for/of
▪ Finance ministers claimed that all the conditions for economic revival were already in place.
▪ In her view, women’s full participation in the labor market is a necessary condition of equality
meet a condition
▪ The Chancellor says that five conditions have to be met before the UK joins the Euro.

children.name: precondition
children.definition: /ˌpriːkənˈdɪʃən/  formal a situation that has to exist before something else can happen: precondition to/for/of
examples: điều kiện tiên quyết
The president has demanded that the rebels turn in their weapons as a precondition to any talks
One of the most obvious preconditions for economic growth is a stable government.

children.name: prerequisite
children.definition: formal something that you must have before something else is possible:
examples: điều kiện tiên quyết
prerequisite for/of
▪ Adequate food and shelter are the minimum prerequisites of a decent life.
▪ Some knowledge of the French language is a prerequisite for employment there.

children.name: when there are limits on what you can do
restrictions
children.definition: /rɪˈstrɪkʃənz/ rulesorlawsthat strictly control what you are allowed to do:
examples: hạn chế , giới hạn
▪ There are certain travel restrictions in effect in certain areas along the border.
restrictions on hạn chế về
▪ Unions are pressing for restrictions on steel imports from Japan.
▪ Because of restrictions on reporting, newspapers were not allowed to cover the story.
impose restrictions: áp đặt han chế
officially order that something must be limited
▪ New restrictions have been imposed on immigration.

children.name: limits
children.definition: /ˈlɪmɪts, ˈlɪməts/  the rules or facts that control someone’s freedom or their ability to do what they want:
examples: giới hạn
limits to giới hạn cho
▪ There are practical limits to the number of cases we can deal with each day.
limits of giới hạn của
▪ He’s well aware of the limits of his knowledge.
within limits trong giới hạn
▪ We want our employees to enjoy themselves, within certain limits.

children.name: limited
children.definition: be /biː ˈlɪmtd/  to not be able to do everything that you want because things are not available, there are rules or laws about it etc: bị giới hạn
examples: ▪ Our choice of shops is somewhat limited because we don’t have a car.
be limited to bị giới hạn đối với
▪ We’re limited to two weeks of vacation a year, so a three-week safari isn’t possible.
be limited by bị giới hạn bởi
▪ Many Hong Kong performers are limited by their lack of English skills in making the transition to Hollywood.

children.name: restricted
children.definition: be /biː rɪˈstrɪktd/  if something is restricted to a particular amount, time, group etc, there are rules or other conditions limiting it to that amount, time, group etc:
examples: bị hạn chế
▪ Access to the President is restricted.
be restricted to bị hạn chế đối với
▪ In those days, visiting in the hospital was restricted to specific weekend hours only.
be restricted by bị hạn chế bởi
▪ Because Forbes was using his own money, he was not restricted by federal limits on campaign spending.

children.name: limitations
children.definition: /ˌlɪmɪˈteɪʃənz, ˌlɪməˈteɪʃənz/  limits on what someone or something is able to do: hạn chế giới hạn
examples: limitations of giới hạn của
▪ The limitations of the computer system make some operations very difficult.
limitations on giới hạn về
▪ The president was unwilling to accept limitations on his power.
physical limitations giới hạn thể chất
▪ Hikers should know their physical limitations and not take unnecessary risks.

children.name: constraints
children.definition: /kənˈstreɪnts/  facts or conditions that limit what you can do, for example not having enough time, money etc: kiềm chế
examples: ▪ Because of time constraints two acts had to be cut from the show.
constraints of sự kiềm chế của
▪ The constraints of prison life are sometimes too much for people to bear.
be constrained/biː kənˈstreɪnd/ [verb phrase] to be unable to do what you want to do because of facts or conditions, for example, because you do not have enough time or money: kiềm chế, bị hạn chế
▪ Sharon’s options were severely constrained because of the foolish choices she made as a teenager.
be constrained by bị hạn chế bởi
▪ Research is often constrained by lack of sufficient data.

children.name: scope
children.definition: /skəʊp/  the range of things that a particular activity is allowed to include or have an effect on: phạm vi
examples: scope of phạm vi của
▪ A clear statement of the goal and scope of a research project is a useful reference point.
within the scope trong phảm vi
▪ It was determined that the Commissioner had been acting within the scope of his official duties.
beyond/outside the scope ngoài phạm vi
▪ I’m afraid the matter falls outside the scope of this enquiry.
in scope trong phạm vi
▪ Regulations are important in markets that are increasingly international in scope.
of enormous/historic/wide etc scope phạm vi lớn
▪ The ruling party has granted concessions of considerable scope.

children.name: confines
children.definition: /ˈkɒnfaɪnzǁˈkɑːn-/  the limits on a situation, organization, activity etc that control what people are allowed to do: giới hạn
examples: confines of giới hạn của
▪ She felt trapped by the narrow confines of the convent.
within the confines trong giới hạn
▪ We must operate within the confines of the law.
beyond/outside the confines quá giới hạn
▪ Hypothetical thinking goes beyond the confines of everyday experience.

children.name: parameters
children.definition: /pəˈræmɪtəʳz, pəˈræmətəʳz/  a set of limits within which an activity can be done - use this in business, education, or technical contexts: thông số giới hạn
examples: ▪ In the private sector there are clear parameters which surround labour relations.
within/outside the parameters of something trong, ngoài thông số giới hạn của cái gì
▪ It is only within the parameters of a clear set of goals that a national science program can be successful.

children.name: wide
children.definition: adjectiveAMOUNT
examples: describes something that includes a large amount or many different types of thing, or that covers a large range or area
_They sell a widerangeof skin-care products.
_She has a wide experience of teaching, in many different schools.
_The Green Party no longer enjoys wide support (= the support of many people) .

children.name: limit
examples: 1[C usually S] the highest number, speed, temperature etc that is allowed by a law or rule: giới hạn
a 55 mph speed limit
limit for
There’s no age limit for applicants.
limit to/on
My wife and I set a limit on how much we spend on clothes.
above/over/below a limit
Pesticide levels in drinking water are already above legal limits in many areas.
set a limit(alsoimpose a limitformal)Set a time limit for the completion of the task.
put a limit on somethingWe have to put a limit on the number of participants.
exceed a limit(= go beyond a limit )He reported a driver for exceeding the speed limit.
go over a limit(= go beyond a limit )Borrowers who go over the spending limit set by the credit card company are penalised.
an upper/lower limit(= the highest/lowest amount allowed )There is no upper limit on the amount you can borrow.|Ensure the temperature in the aquarium does not fall below the lower limit.
a strict limitThere are strict limits on spending.
a legal limit(= a limit set by law )The alcohol in his blood was four times more than the legal limit.
the speed limitToo many people go over the speed limit in residential areas.
a time limitThe time limit for making a claim is three months.
an age limitThe lower age limit for entering the Royal Marines is sixteen.
a weight/height limitThe weight limit per bag is 20 kilos.
spending limitsThere are strict spending limits imposed by law on all candidates.
term limitsAmerican English(= limits on how much time a politician can spend in office )Should Senators be subject to term limits?
2[C] (alsolimits) the greatest possible amount of something that can exist or be obtained :
limit of
the limits of human knowledge
He’dreached the limitof his patience.
Our finances are alreadystretched to the limit(= we do not have any extra money ).
There’s no limit towhat you can do if you try.

children.name: narrow
children.definition: adjectiveLIMITED
examples: mainly disapprovinglimited to a small area of interest, activity or thought
_They are unable to see beyond the narrow world of the theatre.
_It was regarded as a very narrow interpretation of the law.

children.name: range
children.definition: the limits within which amounts, quantities, ages etc vary
examples: age/price/temperature etc range
toys suitable for children in the pre-school age range
a temperature range of 72–85º,
in/within a ... range
Your blood pressure’s well within the normal range.
in the range (of) something to something
a salary in the range of $25,000 to $30,000
Even the cheapest property wasout ofourprice range(= too expensive for us ).

children.name: range
children.definition: a)to include a variety of different things or people in addition to those mentioned
examples: range from something to something
The show had a massive audience, ranging from children to grandparents.
b)if prices, levels, temperatures etc range from one amount to another, they include both those amounts and anything in between
range from something to something
There were 120 students whose ages ranged from 10 to 18.
range between something and something
The population of these cities ranges between 3 and 5 million.
range in age/size/price etc
The shoes range in price from $25 to $100.

children.name: in an legal document, agreement, contract.
condition
children.definition: /kənˈdɪʃən/  something that is stated in an agreement or contract as being necessary before something else can happen or be allowed:
examples: điều kiện
▪ After two weeks of negotiations the two sides still cannot agree on the conditions.
sau hai tuần tranh cãi, cả hai bên vẫn chưa đồng ý điều kiện
condition of
▪ One of the conditions of the agreement was that both sides would call an immediate ceasefire.
một trong những điều kiện của bản thỏa thuận là cả hai bên sẽ yêu cầu ngừng bắn ngay lập tức
▪ It is a condition of my contract with the university that I spend half of the summer vacation doing research.
Một điều kiện trong bản hợp đồng với trường đại học là tôi phải dài nửa mùa hè để làm nghiên cứu
meet/satisfy a conditiondo what is demanded by a condition
▪ The World Bank will only agree to make this loan if certain conditions are met.
Ngân hàng Thế giới chỉ đồng ý cho vay nếu những điều kiện chắc chắn được đáp ứng
lay down/impose a conditionstate what must be done
▪ The Pentagon laid down strict conditions regarding the export of these weapons.
under the conditions of somethingaccording to what is stated in an agreement
theo điều kiện của cái gì
▪ Under the conditions of the GATT trade agreement, farm subsidies would be gradually phased out.
theo kiền kiện của bản thỏa thuận thương mại GATT, sự giảm bớt nông trại sẽ dần dần được thực hiện

children.name: terms
children.definition: /tɜːʳmz/  the conditions that are stated in a written agreement, contract, or legal document:
examples: điều khoản
terms of
điều khoản của
▪ The president refused to reveal the terms of the peace agreement to the press.
Ngài Tổng thống đã từ chối tiết lộ những điều khoản của bản thỏa thuận hòa bình với Bấo chí
▪ The lawyers think we should alter the terms of our contract with the computer company.
các vị luật sư nghĩ rằng chúng ta nên rút lại các điều khoản của bản hợp đồng với công ty máy tính
under the terms of something according to the terms of an agreement
theo các điều khoản của cái gì
▪ Under the terms of the will, Mallory could only inherit the family home if he agreed to continue living there.
theo như các điều khoản của di chúc, Mallory chỉ có thể thừa kế được căn nhà từ đường nếu anh ta đồng ý tiếp tục sống ở đó

children.name: requirements
children.definition: /rɪˈkwaɪəʳmənts/  a set of things that you must do or must achieve in order to be officially allowed to do or have something:
examples: các thủ tục, yêu cầu
▪ A high grade in mathematics is one of the requirements for entry to medical school.
Điểm toán cao là một trong những yêu cầu để đi vào trường y
meet/satisfy/fulfildrequirementso what is necessary
đáp ứng/thỏa mãn các yêu cầu
▪ The company’s child safety seats did not meet the standards for crash safety
Công ty ghế bảo hộ trẻ em đã không đáp ứng các tiêu chuẩn an toàn
.▪ The business does not satisfy all the requirements necessary to qualify for tax concessions.
Doanh nghiệp không thỏa mãn các yêu cầu cần thiết để có đủ điều kiện để giảm thuế

children.name: proviso
children.definition: /prəˈvaɪzəʊ/  a single condition that you make before you agree to do something:
examples: điều khoản, điều kiện
▪ He agreed to do the work, but there was one proviso - he wanted to be paid in cash.
Anh ta đã đồng ý làm công việc này, nhưng có một điều kiện - anh ta muốn được trả bằng tiền mặt
with the proviso that
với điều kiện là
▪ Bill had left the money to his grandson, with the proviso that it should be spent on his education.
Bill đã để lại tiền cho cháu trai của mình, với điều kiện là số tiền ấy sẽ được chi trả cho việc giáo dục

children.name: stipulation
children.definition: /ˌstɪpjɑˈleɪʃən/  a particular condition that is clearly stated as part of an agreement:
examples: điều kiện
▪ The union is pressing for higher pay but has made no stipulations about the numbers of workers to be employed.
Liên minh đang nài ép lương cao hơn nhưng không có điều kiện về số công nhân được thuê
with the stipulation that
với điều kiện là
▪ The company agreed to hire the law firm, with the stipulation that they hire more women lawyers.
Công ty đồng ý thuê văn phòng luật, với điều kiện là họ thuê nhiều nữ luật sư hơn

children.name: a set of different things of the same general type
range
children.definition: a  of something/ə ˈreɪndʒ əv something/  a set of many different things of the same general type that are available in the same place for the same use: một loạt, đủ loại cái gì đó
examples: ▪ She has an interesting range of hobbies, from stamp-collecting to astronomy.
a wide/broad range of something
▪ Atkins is extremely well educated and able to talk on a broad range of topics.
▪ It was difficult to choose from such a wide range of dishes on the menu.

children.name: spectrum
children.definition: /ˈspektrəm/  a complete range of different types of things or people, especially when those at one end of the range are the opposite of those at the other end: đủ các loại khác nhau
examples: spectrum of
▪ The spectrum of protest activity goes from peaceful to extremely violent.
broad/wide/whole/entire spectrum
▪ Their songs appeal to a broad spectrum of music lovers.
▪ You can find therapists along the whole spectrum, from caring and honest to cool and manipulative.
at one end/the other end of the spectrum
▪ At one end of the spectrum were the Communists, and at the other, the Nationalists.
political spectrum range of political opinions
▪ The announcement has upset people all across the political spectrum.

children.name: selection
children.definition: a number of different things of the same kind that are available for you to choose or use: sự chọn lọc, sự tuyển lựa
examples: ▪ Customers are invited to view the selection at any time.
selection of
▪ The library also has a selection of foreign language videos on the third floor.
wide/broad selection
▪ The shop offers a wide selection of glasses frames to choose from.

children.name: gamut
children.definition: /ˈgæmət/  a complete range of every possible emotion, problem, experience etc:toàn bộ, cả loạt
examples: gamut of
toàn bộ, cả loạt
▪ ‘Fear’ is a word that covers a gamut of different feelings.
a/the whole gamut
toàn bộ, cả loạt
▪ Alternative therapies have been successful with a whole gamut of health problems.
▪ New mothers can experience the whole gamut of emotions, from intense joy to deep depression.
run the gamut
gồm đủ loại
▪ Lodgings run the gamut from rustic cabins to plush hotels.

children.name: boundary
children.definition: noun
examples: the limit of a subject or principle
_Electronic publishing isblurringthe boundaries between dictionaries and encyclopedias.

children.name: to
children.definition: prepositionBETWEEN
examples: used in phrases which show a range
_There must have been thirty to thirty-five (= a number between 30 and 35) people there.

children.name: breadth
children.definition: noun
examples: [ S ] when something includes many different things, features, subjects or qualities
_The breadth of her knowledge is amazing.
_He showed an astonishing breadth of learning for one so young.
